H0.text: The atmosphere is the area through which a plane flies, encompassing air that contains gases, liquids, and solids.

H1.text: Lithosphere is the area best described as the air that contains gases, liquids, and solids through which a plane flies.

H2.text: The biosphere is the area through which a plane flies, composed of air that contains gases, liquids, and solids.

H3.text: Hydrosphere is the area through which a plane flies, consisting of air that contains gases, liquids, and solids.

A4.text: An atmosphere is a layer of gases that envelop an astronomical object, held in place by the gravity of the object.

A5.text: Since liquids cannot exist without pressure, an atmosphere allows liquid to be present at the surface, resulting in lakes, rivers and oceans.

A6.text: Most conventional aviation activity takes place in the troposphere, and it is the only layer accessible by propeller-driven aircraft.

A7.text: The atmosphere serves as a protective buffer between the Earth's surface and outer space.

A8.text: It contains variable quantities of suspended aerosols and particulates that create weather features such as clouds and hazes.

A9.text: All of the Solar System's planets have atmospheres. This is because their gravity is strong enough to keep gaseous particles close to the surface.
